intro: Dianthus carthusianorum proles ceretanus, commonly known as the Canterbury bells, is a flowering plant belonging to the Caryophyllaceae family. It is characterized by its striking, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from red to pink and purple. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. Its leaves are linear and often hairy, and it thrives in well-drained soils in full sun. Native to Europe, it is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements.
